ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about rational choice theory as it pertains to economic modeling and philosophy. We examine where rational choice theory fails and how we can overcome its limitations. Readings are drawn from philosophy, economics (including behavioral economics), and psychology.
I learned more about economic decision making.
Various knowledge of the philosophy of choice theory and related disciplines.

This course gave me a broad overview of rational choice theory, game theory, psychology, cognitive science, and philosophy of science, linking all of them together to evaluate the academic study of economics. I think the most important thing I learned is how to think about and appropriately value models.

I learned the ways that different disciplines approached the way people make decisions, and how to evaluate these frameworks. I was also able to earn a deeper appreciation for the difficulty but importance of modeling.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very chill environment! The discussions and lectures were always thought provoking, and the assignment/grading scheme was reason. A weakness is that some of the problem sets were over the top at first, but they got a lot better as time went on.

strength: interesting topic I had no previous knowledge about
weaknesses: difficult to follow the map of the course through the lectures
Course moves slightly slowly, but content is exceptionally interesting.

This course was taught by in chunks by both Larry Samuelson (econ) and Dan Greco (philosophy), meaning that one prof would teach for a few weeks and then the other would take over for a few weeks. A strength was their knowledge of their respective areas, but a weakness was the way they engaged the class. It was an ~8 person class, but didn't really feel like a seminar because there was so little discussion.

The coursework began too heavy, and since its a multidisciplinary course, problem sets can be a little disorienting as they switch from quantitative questions to philosophical questions. However, the two professors care very much about their respective fields, about their course topic, and about student engagement; they are both really responsive and ready to continue to refine the course with the help of their students. Additionally, both professors are clear and engaging lecturers.

The instructors of this course are, in short, amazing. The lectures were interesting, and I thought that the professors made themselves very available for assistance. I do think that the class would have been more productive if some economics classes (like Intermediate Microeconomics) was listed as a prerequisite, as the problem sets and content in the beginning went super fast. The pace settled down a bit as things continued.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
success: topics and presentations
The lectures could be improved to highlight the main points of the class that are a foundation for the rest of the course.

Don't think there is much room for improvement, seeing the nature of this class. The lectures were good; maybe some functions of Zoom like polling, raise hand function, etc. could have been used more (instead of opening it up for the class to speak verbally), but I don't think that was a big issue. Office hours were run well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes this course is fantastic. Low stakes, very chill and thought provoking. The professors were super nice as well.
Yes, if they are more interested in learning the philosophy and economics involved in thinking about decision making.
Yes I totally would - it was really interesting and very engaging.
Yes

Yes, I would, but only if you have a strong background in economics. Although some of the class is devoted to psychology/behavioral economics and philosophy of science, a good amount of it is economics. Sometimes it got pretty mathy. Otherwise, I thought the course was really interesting and engaging.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: some presentations
Course was a virtual seminar.
The class was technically a lecture, but with a small number of students, it functioned not unlike a seminar.
None; the class was a live virtual lecture (didn't have any section).
